items.text: My opinion of myself changes dramatically based on how others react to me.
items.rationale: Directly captures the dependency of self-worth on external validation, the core of contingent self-esteem.

items.text: A single critical remark can make me feel completely worthless for the rest of the day.
items.rationale: Illustrates the fragility of self-esteem and its vulnerability to external negative feedback.

items.text: When someone praises me, I feel on top of the world, but when they ignore me, I feel like nothing.
items.rationale: Shows the oscillation of self-worth tied to others' attention and approval.

items.text: I need reassurance from others to feel confident about my decisions.
items.rationale: Reflects reliance on external validation for self-assurance, a hallmark of contingent self-esteem.

items.text: My self-worth is heavily influenced by whether people admire me or not.
items.rationale: Directly ties self-worth to admiration from others.

items.text: If I don't receive recognition for something I've done, I start to doubt whether it was any good.
items.rationale: Shows how lack of external validation undermines self-evaluation of one's own accomplishments.

items.text: I feel like a different person depending on whether people around me approve of me.
items.rationale: Captures the unstable sense of self that shifts with social approval.

items.text: When I fail at something publicly, it feels like my entire identity is shattered.
items.rationale: Reflects the catastrophic impact of public failure on a fragile, externally-dependent self-concept.

items.text: I constantly compare myself to others to figure out how I should feel about myself.
items.rationale: Social comparison as a mechanism for self-evaluation is central to contingent self-esteem.

items.text: People close to me would say my mood depends entirely on how much attention I'm getting.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of mood regulation tied to external attention, a behavioral marker of contingent self-esteem.

items.text: I can go from feeling great about myself to feeling terrible in a matter of minutes if someone criticizes me.
items.rationale: Rapid self-esteem fluctuation in response to criticism is a defining feature.

items.text: Without positive feedback from others, I struggle to maintain any sense of self-confidence.
items.rationale: Explicitly states the dependency of confidence on external positive feedback.

items.text: I sometimes feel like I don't really know who I am unless someone else tells me I'm doing well.
items.rationale: Touches on identity diffusion which could relate to Hiding the Self, but the emphasis on needing validation anchors it to contingent self-esteem.

items.text: I tend to seek out people who make me feel important because I can't generate that feeling on my own.
items.rationale: Could overlap with Exploitativeness in terms of using others, but the motivation here is self-esteem regulation rather than instrumental gain.

items.text: When someone doesn't acknowledge my contributions, I feel a surge of anger and worthlessness at the same time.
items.rationale: The anger component could map to Entitlement Rage, but the simultaneous worthlessness suggests the primary driver is fragile, contingent self-esteem.

items.text: Most people are fundamentally mediocre and not worth my time.
items.rationale: Directly expresses contempt and dismissal of others' worth, the core of the Devaluing factor.

items.text: When someone disappoints me, I quickly lose all respect for them.
items.rationale: Reflects the rapid, total devaluation of others following perceived disappointment.

items.text: I often think that the people around me are incompetent.
items.rationale: Chronic perception of others as inferior is a hallmark of narcissistic devaluing.

items.text: Once I see a flaw in someone, it's hard for me to see anything good about them anymore.
items.rationale: Splitting and all-or-nothing devaluation triggered by perceived flaws.

items.text: I secretly look down on most of the people I interact with daily.
items.rationale: Covert contempt for others is a core expression of the Devaluing dimension.

items.text: People who can't keep up with me intellectually bore me to tears.
items.rationale: Dismissing others based on perceived intellectual inferiority reflects devaluing tendencies.

items.text: I find it hard to respect authority figures because most of them don't deserve their positions.
items.rationale: Devaluing extends to authority figures, reflecting a pervasive contempt for others' competence.

items.text: When a friend makes a mistake, I tend to write them off rather than give them another chance.
items.rationale: Behavioral description of devaluing others after perceived failures.

items.text: I often feel surrounded by people who just don't measure up.
items.rationale: Chronic sense of others' inadequacy is central to the Devaluing construct.

items.text: His colleagues notice that he dismisses anyone who disagrees with him as stupid or uninformed.
items.rationale: Third-person behavioral observation of devaluing others who challenge the person's views.

items.text: I tend to idealize new people in my life but then quickly become disillusioned with them.
items.rationale: The idealization-devaluation cycle is a classic narcissistic pattern, with the endpoint being devaluation.

items.text: I think most people's achievements are overrated and undeserved.
items.rationale: Minimizing others' accomplishments is a direct expression of devaluing.

items.text: I sometimes feel contempt for people who show vulnerability or weakness.
items.rationale: Contempt for vulnerability could also relate to Hiding the Self (projecting one's own discomfort with vulnerability), but the primary expression is devaluing others.

items.text: When someone I once admired lets me down, I feel disgusted and want nothing to do with them.
items.rationale: The disgust response and total withdrawal could overlap with Entitlement Rage, but the emphasis on loss of regard anchors it to Devaluing.

items.text: People who fail to meet my standards deserve to be cut out of my life, and I feel justified in doing so.
items.rationale: The sense of justification and the punitive quality could map to Entitlement Rage, but the core mechanism is devaluing others based on unmet standards.

items.text: When someone treats me unfairly, I feel an intense rage that is hard to control.
items.rationale: Intense, disproportionate anger in response to perceived unfairness is the hallmark of entitlement rage.

items.text: I become furious when I don't get the respect I deserve.
items.rationale: Anger triggered by perceived lack of deserved respect directly captures entitlement rage.

items.text: If someone cuts in front of me in line, I feel a disproportionate surge of anger.
items.rationale: Everyday behavioral example of rage triggered by perceived violation of one's entitled position.

items.text: I have lashed out at people who I felt were not giving me the treatment I was owed.
items.rationale: Behavioral admission of aggressive responses driven by entitlement beliefs.

items.text: When things don't go my way, I feel a burning resentment that can last for days.
items.rationale: Persistent resentment following thwarted expectations reflects the sustained quality of entitlement rage.

items.text: I have been told that I overreact when I feel slighted, but I think my reactions are perfectly justified.
items.rationale: Captures both the disproportionate anger and the self-justification typical of entitlement rage.

items.text: Being overlooked for a promotion or award makes me want to retaliate against whoever made that decision.
items.rationale: Retaliatory impulses following perceived injustice in status allocation are core to entitlement rage.

items.text: Her partner says she becomes explosive whenever she feels her needs aren't being prioritized.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of explosive anger tied to unmet entitlement expectations in relationships.

items.text: I feel personally attacked when someone questions my judgment or authority.
items.rationale: Perceiving challenges to authority as personal attacks reflects the narcissistic injury that fuels entitlement rage.

items.text: I have fantasized about getting revenge on people who have wronged me.
items.rationale: Revenge fantasies are a cognitive manifestation of entitlement rage.

items.text: When I'm not treated as special, I feel an anger that seems to come from deep inside me.
items.rationale: Links the expectation of special treatment to a visceral anger response.

items.text: I can hold a grudge for years against someone who I feel disrespected me.
items.rationale: Long-lasting grudges rooted in perceived disrespect reflect the enduring nature of entitlement rage.

items.text: Sometimes my anger at being treated unfairly makes me want to withdraw from everyone entirely.
items.rationale: The withdrawal component could relate to Hiding the Self, but the primary driver is anger at perceived unfairness.

items.text: I get angry when people don't recognize how much I've sacrificed for them.
items.rationale: Could overlap with Self-Sacrificing Self-Enhancement, but the emphasis on anger at lack of recognition anchors it to entitlement rage.

items.text: When people fail to appreciate me, I feel both enraged and deeply hurt, and I want them to suffer for it.
items.rationale: The deep hurt component could map to Contingent Self-Esteem, but the desire for others to suffer is more characteristic of Entitlement Rage.

items.text: I am good at getting people to do things for me without them realizing my true intentions.
items.rationale: Directly describes manipulative behavior and concealed motives, core to exploitativeness.

items.text: I see most social interactions as opportunities to advance my own interests.
items.rationale: Instrumental view of relationships is a defining feature of narcissistic exploitativeness.

items.text: I don't feel guilty about using people if it helps me get what I want.
items.rationale: Lack of guilt about using others directly captures the callous, self-serving nature of exploitativeness.

items.text: I know exactly what to say to get people on my side, even if I don't mean it.
items.rationale: Strategic impression management for personal gain is a behavioral marker of exploitativeness.

items.text: I have taken credit for other people's work when it benefited me.
items.rationale: Concrete exploitative behavior — appropriating others' achievements for personal gain.

items.text: I tend to befriend people who can be useful to me in some way.
items.rationale: Instrumental friendship selection is a classic expression of exploitative interpersonal orientation.

items.text: I can be very charming when I need something from someone.
items.rationale: Strategic deployment of charm for instrumental purposes reflects exploitative interpersonal style.

items.text: His friends have noticed that he only reaches out when he needs a favor.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of transactional relationship pattern characteristic of exploitativeness.

items.text: I have manipulated someone's emotions to get them to do what I wanted.
items.rationale: Direct admission of emotional manipulation, a core exploitative behavior.

items.text: I view relationships primarily in terms of what I can gain from them.
items.rationale: Explicitly transactional view of relationships is central to exploitativeness.

items.text: I am skilled at identifying people's weaknesses and using them to my advantage.
items.rationale: Predatory social cognition — identifying and leveraging vulnerabilities — is a hallmark of exploitativeness.

items.text: If bending the truth gets me ahead, I don't see the problem with it.
items.rationale: Moral flexibility in service of self-advancement reflects the ethical disregard inherent in exploitativeness.

items.text: I sometimes pretend to care about someone's problems so they'll feel indebted to me later.
items.rationale: The feigned caring could overlap with Self-Sacrificing Self-Enhancement, but the explicit goal of creating indebtedness anchors it to exploitativeness.

items.text: I find it easy to drop people from my life once they are no longer useful to me.
items.rationale: Could overlap with Devaluing in terms of discarding others, but the utilitarian framing points to exploitativeness.

items.text: I help people strategically, knowing that they will owe me something in return.
items.rationale: The helping behavior could map to Self-Sacrificing Self-Enhancement, but the explicit strategic calculation and expectation of return favors is more exploitative.

items.text: I often daydream about achieving something so extraordinary that the whole world would take notice.
items.rationale: Fantasies of extraordinary achievement and global recognition are the essence of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I frequently imagine myself in positions of great power and influence.
items.rationale: Recurrent fantasies of power and influence directly capture grandiose fantasy content.

items.text: In my mind, I am destined for greatness that others simply cannot understand yet.
items.rationale: Belief in a special destiny not yet recognized by others is a core grandiose fantasy theme.

items.text: I spend a lot of time imagining scenarios where I am the hero who saves the day.
items.rationale: Heroic rescue fantasies reflect grandiose self-imagery.

items.text: I sometimes picture myself giving a speech to thousands of adoring fans.
items.rationale: Fantasy of mass adoration is a prototypical grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I believe I have a unique talent or gift that will eventually be recognized by everyone.
items.rationale: Conviction of possessing unrecognized special abilities is central to grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I often fantasize about being incredibly wealthy and living a life of luxury.
items.rationale: Fantasies of unlimited wealth and luxury are classic grandiose fantasy content.

items.text: I imagine myself outperforming everyone in my field and being celebrated for it.
items.rationale: Fantasies of supreme competence and resulting celebration capture grandiose fantasy.

items.text: Sometimes I get lost in elaborate daydreams about how different my life would be if people truly saw my potential.
items.rationale: Elaborate daydreams about unrecognized potential are a hallmark of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I have a vivid inner world where I accomplish things that seem impossible in real life.
items.rationale: Rich fantasy life centered on impossible achievements reflects grandiose fantasy.

items.text: She often talks about future plans that seem wildly unrealistic, as if she truly believes she is destined for fame.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of unrealistic plans driven by belief in a special destiny.

items.text: I picture myself being interviewed on television about my remarkable accomplishments.
items.rationale: Specific fantasy of media attention for achievements is a concrete grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I sometimes feel frustrated that my real life doesn't match the extraordinary life I imagine for myself.
items.rationale: The frustration component could relate to Contingent Self-Esteem, but the primary content is the discrepancy between fantasy and reality.

items.text: I daydream about being so successful that everyone who ever doubted me would regret it.
items.rationale: The revenge element could overlap with Entitlement Rage, but the primary mechanism is the grandiose fantasy of vindication through success.

items.text: I imagine myself being so powerful that no one could ever hurt or disrespect me again.
items.rationale: The defensive quality — fantasy as protection against narcissistic injury — could map to Entitlement Rage or Hiding the Self, but the content is fundamentally a grandiose power fantasy.

items.text: I rarely let people see the real me because I'm afraid they would think less of me.
items.rationale: Concealing the authentic self due to fear of negative evaluation is the core of Hiding the Self.

items.text: I put on a confident front even when I feel insecure inside.
items.rationale: Maintaining a false confident exterior to mask inner insecurity directly captures self-concealment.

items.text: I am very careful about what I reveal about myself to others.
items.rationale: Deliberate self-monitoring and information control reflect the guarded nature of Hiding the Self.

items.text: If people knew what I was really like, they would be disappointed.
items.rationale: Belief that the true self is disappointing drives the concealment behavior central to this factor.

items.text: I avoid deep emotional conversations because they might expose my vulnerabilities.
items.rationale: Avoidance of emotional intimacy to protect against vulnerability exposure is a key behavioral marker.

items.text: I have created a persona that I present to the world that is very different from who I really am.
items.rationale: Explicit acknowledgment of maintaining a false self is the essence of Hiding the Self.

items.text: I would rather people admire a version of me that isn't real than see the flawed person I actually am.
items.rationale: Preference for false admiration over authentic connection captures the defensive function of self-concealment.

items.text: I feel deeply ashamed of certain aspects of myself that I keep hidden from everyone.
items.rationale: Shame-driven concealment of perceived flaws is central to Hiding the Self.

items.text: Even with my closest friends, there are parts of myself I would never share.
items.rationale: Pervasive self-concealment even in close relationships reflects the depth of this tendency.

items.text: His therapist notes that he presents a polished exterior but becomes anxious when asked to discuss his true feelings.
items.rationale: Clinical third-person observation of the discrepancy between presented self and anxiety about authentic disclosure.

items.text: I go to great lengths to make sure no one sees me struggle or fail.
items.rationale: Active concealment of struggle and failure reflects the protective function of Hiding the Self.

items.text: I feel like I'm constantly performing a role rather than being myself around others.
items.rationale: Chronic sense of performing rather than being authentic is a subjective experience central to this factor.

items.text: I worry that if I let my guard down, people will use my weaknesses against me.
items.rationale: The fear of exploitation could overlap with a paranoid interpersonal style, but the self-protective concealment is the primary mechanism.

items.text: I keep my true opinions to myself because I'm afraid of being judged or rejected.
items.rationale: Could relate to Contingent Self-Esteem through fear of rejection, but the emphasis on concealment of authentic views anchors it to Hiding the Self.

items.text: I present myself as more successful than I actually am because I can't bear for people to see me as ordinary.
items.rationale: The need to appear extraordinary could map to Grandiose Fantasy, but the emphasis on concealing the ordinary true self places it primarily in Hiding the Self.

items.text: I go out of my way to help others, and I feel resentful when they don't appreciate the sacrifices I've made.
items.rationale: Combines self-sacrifice with resentment at lack of appreciation, the defining dynamic of this factor.

items.text: I often put others' needs before my own, but deep down I expect them to recognize how selfless I am.
items.rationale: Explicitly captures the covert expectation of recognition that underlies ostensibly selfless behavior.

items.text: I pride myself on being the person everyone turns to in a crisis, even when it exhausts me.
items.rationale: Self-image built around being indispensable to others, even at personal cost, is central to this factor.

items.text: I have a hard time saying no to people because I want them to see me as generous and caring.
items.rationale: Inability to set boundaries driven by desire to maintain a generous self-image reflects self-sacrificing self-enhancement.

items.text: I sometimes remind people of the things I've done for them so they don't forget.
items.rationale: Actively ensuring others remember one's sacrifices reveals the self-enhancing motive behind the self-sacrifice.

items.text: I feel morally superior to people who don't sacrifice as much as I do for others.
items.rationale: Moral superiority derived from self-sacrifice is a key cognitive feature of this factor.

items.text: I give and give to others, but I keep a mental tally of everything I've done.
items.rationale: The mental scorekeeping reveals the transactional nature beneath the self-sacrificing surface.

items.text: People see me as incredibly selfless, but honestly, I need them to see me that way.
items.rationale: Explicit acknowledgment that the selfless image serves a narcissistic need captures the essence of this factor.

items.text: I feel hurt and unappreciated when my efforts to help others go unnoticed.
items.rationale: Emotional pain from unrecognized self-sacrifice reflects the covert narcissistic need underlying this pattern.

items.text: Her family describes her as someone who does everything for everyone but then makes them feel guilty about it.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of the guilt-inducing quality of self-sacrificing behavior.

items.text: I believe that my willingness to sacrifice for others makes me a better person than most.
items.rationale: Explicit belief in moral superiority through self-sacrifice is a defining cognition of this factor.

items.text: I often take on more than I can handle because I want to be seen as the one who holds everything together.
items.rationale: Overextending oneself to maintain an indispensable self-image captures the self-enhancing motive.

items.text: When I help someone and they don't thank me profusely, I feel a quiet bitterness inside.
items.rationale: The bitterness could shade into Entitlement Rage, but the context of helping and expecting gratitude anchors it to self-sacrificing self-enhancement.

items.text: I sometimes wonder if I help people mainly because it makes me feel important rather than because I truly care.
items.rationale: This reflective insight into one's own motives could suggest psychological mindedness beyond this factor, but the content directly addresses the self-enhancing motive behind helping.

items.text: I exhaust myself taking care of others and then feel furious when no one takes care of me in return.
items.rationale: The fury at unreciprocated care could map to Entitlement Rage, but the self-sacrificing context and expectation of reciprocity place it primarily in Self-Sacrificing Self-Enhancement.
